description: From post-classical Latin disculpatus, past participle of disculpare (“to disculpate”), from dis- + culpare (“to blame”), culpa (“fault”).

verbs.description: disculpate (third-person singular simple present disculpates, present participle disculpating, simple past and past participle disculpated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To free from blame or the imputation of a fault; to exonerate. [from 17th c.]
examples: He […] endeavoured to disculpate the youth, and left no method untried to soften the tyrant's rage.
